001package squidpony.squidgrid.gui.gdx;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.Application;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.Gdx;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.LifecycleListener;
006import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Texture;
007import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.BitmapFont;
008import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextureAtlas;
009import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextureRegion;
010import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.glutils.ShaderProgram;
011import squidpony.squidmath.StatefulRNG;
012
013/**
014 * Default BitmapFonts, a sample image, "stretchable" fonts and icons, and a central RNG for use with LibGDX.
015 * All but one of the resources here need to be downloaded separately, to avoid bloating the size of the dependency jar
016 * with many fonts that a game probably won't use. You can download assets in a jar with a release of SquidLib, or
017 * individually from https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/tree/master/assets . The assets you choose should go in the
018 * android/assets (core/assets if you don't have an Android project) subfolder of your game if you use the normal libGDX
019 * setup tool or SquidSetup, or the assets subfolder if you use czyzby's alternate setup tool,
020 * https://github.com/czyzby/gdx-setup . They should not be placed in subdirectories of assets, otherwise this won't be
021 * able to find them.
022 * <br>
023 * The fonts provided are mostly monospaced, with most looking rather similar (straight orthogonal lines and right-angle
024 * curves), but some that look... better than the rest. For monospaced fonts that could be used on a grid in SquidPanel
025 * or SquidLayers, it is recommended that you use a "stretchable" font (which use a signed distance field, or SDF,
026 * effect to stretch smoothly) or a "crisp" font (which use a multi-channel signed distance field, or MSDF, effect to
027 * stretch smoothly and remain sharp at very high zooms). For some usage you may want a TextFamily instead of a normal
028 * TextCellFactory or BitmapFont; these TextFamily fonts store regular, bold, italic, and bold-italic faces in one file,
029 * and {@link GDXMarkup} can produce text that will render in those faces. Some good choices for fonts here are
030 * Iosevka, which comes in a sans-serif version with {@link #getStretchableLeanFont()}, {@link #getCrispLeanFont()}, 
031 * {@link #getCrispLeanFamily()}, and more, as well as a slab-serif version with {@link #getStretchableSlabFont()},
032 * {@link #getCrispSlabFont()}, and {@link #getCrispSlabFamily()}, among others, as well as Inconsolata-LGC, which is
033 * more geometric sans-serif accessible with {@link #getStretchableFont()}, or (well-suited for square glyphs)
034 * {@link #getStretchableSquareFont()} (it does not have a crisp variety). Another is Computer Modern, accessible by
035 * {@link #getStretchableTypewriterFont()}, which has a chunky, ornamented style. For variable-width fonts
036 * that can be used in TextPanel, among others, you can use the recommended crisp font family Noto Serif
037 * with {@link #getCrispPrintFamily()}, or for stretchable fonts there's the serif font Gentium with
038 * {@link #getStretchablePrintFont()} or Noto Sans with {@link #getStretchableCleanFont()} (Noto Sans currently has
039 * problems that Noto Serif does not have). All of the fonts so far support the Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic alphabets.
040 * <br>
041 * If you can't decide, go with {@link #getCrispLeanFont()} or {@link #getCrispSlabFont()}, which return TextCellFactory
042 * objects, and call their .width(int), .height(int), and .initBySize() methods to make them the size (and aspect ratio)
043 * you want. You can use stretchable or crisp fonts with equal width and height to make
044 * a horizontally-stretched version of a square font instead of the existing square fonts that add blank space.
045 * <br>
046 * The most Latin script support for a monospaced font is in the font Mandrill, accessible by getDefaultUnicodeFont()
047 * and getLargeUnicodeFont() in two different sizes, and the latter should be suitable for everything from Spanish and
048 * French, to Polish to Vietnamese. You can use Gentium for even better language support with a variable-width font in
049 * TextPanel or the like; it is accessible with getStretchablePrintFont(). Google's Noto font also supports many glyphs
050 * in a variable-width format; it is accessible with getStretchableCleanFont() but may have some issues with baseline
051 * level changing and character-to-character alignment seeming too high or low.
052 * <br>
053 * The sample image is a tentacle taken from a public domain icon collection graciously released by Henrique Lazarini;
054 * it's fitting for SquidLib to have a tentacle as a logo or something, I guess?
055 * <br>
056 * The icons are from http://game-icons.net , there are over 2000 of them, and they're among the only images that should
057 * both be recolor-able easily (like chars in a font) and resize-able easily if you use a stretchable font at the same
058 * time. The stretchable font TextCellFactories do some work with shaders that makes most images look incorrect, but
059 * allow distance field fonts and these distance field icons to resize smoothly. Mixing stretchable fonts with
060 * non-stretchable images or fonts is not a great idea, and usually involves a slow shader change back and forth.
061 * <br>
062 * You can get a default RNG with getGuiRandom(); this should probably not be reused for non-GUI-related randomness,
063 * but is meant instead to be used wherever randomized purely-aesthetic effects are needed, such as a jiggling effect.
064 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 7/11/2015.
065 */
066public class DefaultResources implements LifecycleListener {

150    public static final String vertexShader = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
151            + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
152            + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
153            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
154            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
155            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
156            + "\n"
157            + "void main() {\n"
158            + " v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
159            + " v_color.a = v_color.a * (255.0/254.0);\n"
160            + " v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
161            + " gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
162            + "}\n";
163
164    public static final String fragmentShader = "#ifdef GL_ES\n"
165            + " precision mediump float;\n"
166            + " precision mediump int;\n"
167            + "#endif\n"
168            + "\n"
169            + "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n"
170            + "uniform float u_smoothing;\n"
171            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
172            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
173            + "\n"
174            + "void main() {\n"
175            + "  if (u_smoothing > 0.0) {\n"
176            + "    vec4 box = vec4(v_texCoords-0.000125, v_texCoords+0.000125);\n"
177            + "    float asum = smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, texture2D(u_texture, box.xy).a) +\n"
178            + "                 smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, texture2D(u_texture, box.zw).a) +\n"
179            + "                 smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, texture2D(u_texture, box.xw).a) +\n"
180            + "                 smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, texture2D(u_texture, box.zy).a);\n"
181            + "    gl_FragColor = vec4(v_color.rgb, ((smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords).a) + 0.5 * asum) / 3.0) * v_color.a);\n"
182            + "  } else {\n"
183            + "         gl_FragColor = v_color * texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords);\n"
184            + "  }\n"
185            + "}\n";

192//            + "uniform float u_smoothing;\n"
193//            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"

195//            + "\n"
196//            + "void main() {\n"

205    public static final String msdfFragmentShader =  "#ifdef GL_ES\n"
206            + " precision mediump float;\n"
207            + " precision mediump int;\n"
208            + "#endif\n"
209            + "\n"
210            + "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n"
211            + "uniform float u_smoothing;\n"
212            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
213            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
214            + "\n"
215            + "void main() {\n"
216            + "  vec3 sdf = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords).rgb;\n"
217            + "  gl_FragColor = vec4(v_color.rgb, clamp((max(min(sdf.r, sdf.g), min(max(sdf.r, sdf.g), sdf.b)) - 0.5) * u_smoothing + 0.5, 0.0, 1.0) * v_color.a);\n"
218            //+ " float dist = (max(min(sdf.r, sdf.g), min(max(sdf.r, sdf.g), sdf.b)) - 0.5) / (2.75 * u_smoothing);\n"
219            //+ " float d = u_smoothing * 1.75;\n" 
220            //+ " float d = fwidth(dist);\n"
221            //+ " float alpha = clamp(dist + 0.5, 0.0, 1.0);\n"
222            //+ " float alpha = smoothstep(-d, d, dist);\n"
223            //+ " if(alpha == 0) { discard; }\n"
224            //+ "       gl_FragColor = vec4(v_color.rgb, alpha * v_color.a);\n"
225
226            //+ "        vec3 sdf;\n"
227            //+ "        vec4 box = vec4(v_texCoords-0.0000625, v_texCoords+0.0000625);\n"
228            //+ "  sdf = texture2D(u_texture, box.xy).rgb;\n"
229            //+ "        float asum = clamp((max(min(sdf.r, sdf.g), min(max(sdf.r, sdf.g), sdf.b)) - 0.5) / (6.0 * u_smoothing) + 0.5, 0.0, 0.5);\n"
230            //+ "  sdf = texture2D(u_texture, box.zw).rgb;\n"
231            //+ "  asum = asum + clamp((max(min(sdf.r, sdf.g), min(max(sdf.r, sdf.g), sdf.b)) - 0.5) / (6.0 * u_smoothing) + 0.5, 0.0, 0.5); +\n"
232            //+ "  sdf = texture2D(u_texture, box.xw).rgb;\n"
233            //+ "  asum = asum + clamp((max(min(sdf.r, sdf.g), min(max(sdf.r, sdf.g), sdf.b)) - 0.5) / (6.0 * u_smoothing) + 0.5, 0.0, 0.5); +\n"
234            //+ "  sdf = texture2D(u_texture, box.zy).rgb;\n"
235            //+ "  asum = asum + clamp((max(min(sdf.r, sdf.g), min(max(sdf.r, sdf.g), sdf.b)) - 0.5) / (6.0 * u_smoothing) + 0.5, 0.0, 0.5); +\n"
236            //+ "  sdf = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords).rgb;\n"
237            //+ "  gl_FragColor = vec4(v_color.rgb, clamp(((max(min(sdf.r, sdf.g), min(max(sdf.r, sdf.g), sdf.b)) - 0.625) / (3.0 * u_smoothing) + 0.625 + asum) / 3.0, 0.0, 1.0) * v_color.a);\n"
238            + "}\n";
239    /**
240     * An alternate shader based on {@link DefaultResources#fragmentShader}, but this draws outlines around characters.
241     * Only works with distance field fonts. You probably need to create a new ShaderProgram to use this, which would
242     * look like {@code new ShaderProgram(DefaultResources.vertexShader, DefaultResources.outlineFragmentShader)}, and
243     * would assign this to your TextCellFactory's {@link TextCellFactory#shader} field after the TextCellFactory is
244     * fully initialized (calling {@link TextCellFactory#initBySize()}) will set the shader back to the default).
245     */
246    public static final String outlineFragmentShader = "#ifdef GL_ES\n"
247            + "precision mediump float;\n"
248            + "precision mediump int;\n"
249            + "#endif\n"
250            + "\n"
251            + "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n"
252            + "uniform float u_smoothing;\n"
253            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
254            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
255            + "\n"
256            + "void main() {\n"
257            + "  if(u_smoothing <= 0.0) {\n"
258            + "    float smoothing = -u_smoothing;\n"
259            + "    vec4 box = vec4(v_texCoords-0.000125, v_texCoords+0.000125);\n"
260            + "    vec2 sample0 = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords).ra;\n"
261            + "    vec2 sample1 = texture2D(u_texture, box.xy).ra;\n"
262            + "    vec2 sample2 = texture2D(u_texture, box.zw).ra;\n"
263            + "    vec2 sample3 = texture2D(u_texture, box.xw).ra;\n"
264            + "    vec2 sample4 = texture2D(u_texture, box.zy).ra;\n"
265            + "    float asum = smoothstep(0.5 - smoothing, 0.5 + smoothing, min(sample0.x, sample0.y)) + 0.5 * (\n"
266            + "                 smoothstep(0.5 - smoothing, 0.5 + smoothing, min(sample1.x, sample1.y)) +\n"
267            + "                 smoothstep(0.5 - smoothing, 0.5 + smoothing, min(sample2.x, sample2.y)) +\n"
268            + "                 smoothstep(0.5 - smoothing, 0.5 + smoothing, min(sample3.x, sample3.y)) +\n"
269            + "                 smoothstep(0.5 - smoothing, 0.5 + smoothing, min(sample4.x, sample4.y)));\n"
270            + "    gl_FragColor = vec4(v_color.rgb, (asum / 3.0) * v_color.a);\n"
271            + "  } else {\n"
272            + "    vec2 radistance = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords).ra;\n"
273            + "    float distance = min(radistance.x, radistance.y);\n"
274//            + "          vec2 box = vec2(0.0, 0.00375 * (u_smoothing + 0.0825));\n"
275//            + "          float asum = 0.7 * (smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, distance) + \n"
276//            + "                   smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords + box.xy).a) +\n"
277//            + "                   smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords - box.xy).a) +\n"
278//            + "                   smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords + box.yx).a) +\n"
279//            + "                   smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords - box.yx).a)),\n"
280            + "    vec4 box = vec4(v_texCoords-0.000625, v_texCoords+0.000625);\n"
281            + "    vec2 sample0 = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords).ra;\n"
282            + "    vec2 sample1 = texture2D(u_texture, box.xy).ra;\n"
283            + "    vec2 sample2 = texture2D(u_texture, box.zw).ra;\n"
284            + "    vec2 sample3 = texture2D(u_texture, box.xw).ra;\n"
285            + "    vec2 sample4 = texture2D(u_texture, box.zy).ra;\n"
286            + "    float asum = smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, min(sample0.x, sample0.y)) + 0.5 * (\n"
287            + "                 smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, min(sample1.x, sample1.y)) +\n"
288            + "                 smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, min(sample2.x, sample2.y)) +\n"
289            + "                 smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, min(sample3.x, sample3.y)) +\n"
290            + "                 smoothstep(0.5 - u_smoothing, 0.5 + u_smoothing, min(sample4.x, sample4.y))),\n"
291//            + "                 char = step(distance, 0.35);\n"
292            + "                 fancy = step(0.55, distance);\n"
293//            + "                 outline = clamp((distance * 0.8 - 0.415) * 18.0, 0.0, 1.0);\n"
294            + "    gl_FragColor = vec4(v_color.rgb * fancy, (asum + step(0.3, distance)) * v_color.a);\n"
295            + "  }\n"
296            + "}\n";
297    /**
298     * An alternate shader based on {@link DefaultResources#msdfFragmentShader}, but this draws outlines around
299     * characters. This should be sharper than {@link #outlineFragmentShader},  but only works with MSDF (crisp) fonts.
300     * Unlike that shader, this doesn't have special behavior for negative
301     * {@link TextCellFactory#getSmoothingMultiplier()} values, though that may be added later.
302     * You probably need to create a new ShaderProgram to use this, which would look like
303     * {@code new ShaderProgram(DefaultResources.vertexShader, DefaultResources.msdfOutlineFragmentShader)}, and
304     * would assign this to your TextCellFactory's {@link TextCellFactory#shader} field after the TextCellFactory is
305     * fully initialized (calling {@link TextCellFactory#initBySize()}) will set the shader back to the default).
306     */
307    public static final String msdfOutlineFragmentShader =  "#ifdef GL_ES\n"
308            + " precision mediump float;\n"
309            + " precision mediump int;\n"
310            + "#endif\n"
311            + "\n"
312            + "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n"
313            + "uniform float u_smoothing;\n"
314            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
315            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
316            + "\n"
317            + "void main() {\n"
318            + "  vec3 sdf = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords).rgb;\n"
319//            + "  float distance = (max(min(sdf.r, sdf.g), min(max(sdf.r, sdf.g), sdf.b)) - 0.425);\n"
320//            + "  gl_FragColor = vec4(step(3.5 * u_smoothing, distance * 0.75) * v_color.rgb, clamp((distance / (3.4 * u_smoothing)) + 0.9125, 0.0, 1.0) * v_color.a);\n"
321
322            //+ "  float cd = clamp(distance, 0.0, 1.0);"
323
324            + "  float d = ((max(min(sdf.r, sdf.g), min(max(sdf.r, sdf.g), sdf.b))) - 0.4);\n"
325            + "  float block = step(-0.4999999, d);\n"
326            + "  float nice = step(0.24999999, d);\n"
327            + "  gl_FragColor = vec4(v_color.rgb * nice, clamp(d * u_smoothing + (block + 1.0) * 0.5, 0.0, 1.0) * v_color.a);\n"
328            + "}\n";
329
330    private SquidColorCenter scc = null;
331    private Texture tentacle = null;
332    private TextureRegion tentacleRegion = null;
333    private StatefulRNG guiRandom;
334
335    private static DefaultResources instance = null;
336
337    static BitmapFont copyFont(BitmapFont font)
338    {
339        if(font == null) return new BitmapFont();
340        return new BitmapFont(new BitmapFont.BitmapFontData(font.getData().getFontFile(), false),
341                font.getRegions(), font.usesIntegerPositions());
342    }
343    private DefaultResources()
344    {
345        if(Gdx.app == null)
346            throw new IllegalStateException("Gdx.app cannot be null; initialize GUI-using objects in create() or later.");
347        Gdx.app.addLifecycleListener(this);
348    }
349
350    private static void initialize()
351    {
352        if(instance == null)
353            instance = new DefaultResources();
354    }
355
356    /**
357     * Gets the one font guaranteed to be included in libGDX, which is Arial at size 15 px.
358     * @return the BitmapFont representing Arial.ttf at size 15 px
359     */
360    public static BitmapFont getIncludedFont()
361    {
362        initialize();
363        if(instance.arial15 == null)
364        {
365            try {
366                instance.arial15 = new BitmapFont();
367                //instance.narrow1.getData().padBottom = instance.narrow1.getDescent();
368            } catch (Exception e) {
369            }
370        }
371        return copyFont(instance.arial15);
372    }
373    /**
374     * Returns a 12x12px, stretched but curvaceous font as an embedded resource. Caches it for later calls.
375     * <br>
376     * Needs files:
377     * <ul>
378     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Zodiac-Square-12x12.fnt</li>
379     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Zodiac-Square-12x12.png</li>
380     * </ul>
381     * @return the BitmapFont object representing Zodiac-Square.ttf at size 16 pt
382     */
383    public static BitmapFont getDefaultFont()
384    {
385        initialize();
386        if(instance.square1 == null)
387        {
388            try {
389                instance.square1 = new BitmapFont(Gdx.files.internal(squareName), Gdx.files.internal(squareTexture), false);
390                //instance.square1.getData().padBottom = instance.square1.getDescent();
391            } catch (Exception e) {
392            }
393        }
394        return copyFont(instance.square1);
395    }

587    /**
588     * Returns a 25x25px, very smooth and generally good-looking font (based on Inconsolata) as an embedded resource.
589     * This font fully supports Latin, Greek, Cyrillic, and of particular interest to SquidLib, Box Drawing characters.
590     * This variant is (almost) perfectly square, and box drawing characters should line up at size 25x25 px, but other
591     * glyphs will have much more horizontal spacing than in other fonts. Caches the font for later calls. You may want
592     * {@link #getStretchableSquareFont()} instead, which is the same font but can stretch smoothly to most sizes.
593     * <br>
594     * Needs files:
595     * <ul>
596     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Inconsolata-LGC-Square-25x25.fnt</li>
597     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Inconsolata-LGC-Square-25x25.png</li>
598     * </ul>
599     * @return the BitmapFont object representing Inconsolata-LGC-Square at size 25x25 pixels
600     */
601    public static BitmapFont getSquareSmoothFont()
602    {
603        initialize();
604        if(instance.smoothSquare == null)
605        {
606            try {
607                instance.smoothSquare = new BitmapFont(Gdx.files.internal(smoothSquareName), Gdx.files.internal(smoothSquareTexture), false);
608                //instance.smoothSquare.getData().padBottom = instance.smoothSquare.getDescent();
609            } catch (Exception e) {
610            }
611        }
612        return copyFont(instance.smoothSquare);
613    }
614    /**
615     * Returns a 4x10px, extremely thin font (that may be barely legible) as an embedded resource.
616     * The font builds on work by Christian Munk in his font called Monotwist, making some changes for legibility.
617     * This font has the lowest width of any font asset distributed with SquidLib. Caches the font for later calls.
618     * Attribution to Christian Munk (or the username he used, CMunk) is required to use this font; this is in the
619     * license file linked below.
620     * <br>
621     * Needs files:
622     * <ul>
623     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Monty-4x10.fnt</li>
624     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Monty-4x10.png</li>
625     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Monty-license.txt</li>
626     * </ul>
627     * @return the BitmapFont object representing Monty.ttf at size 8 pt
628     */
629    public static BitmapFont getTinyFont()
630    {
631        initialize();

633        {
634            try {
635                instance.tiny = new BitmapFont(Gdx.files.internal(tinyName), Gdx.files.internal(tinyTexture), false);
636                //instance.narrow1.getData().padBottom = instance.narrow1.getDescent();
637            } catch (Exception e) {
638            }
639        }
640        return copyFont(instance.tiny);
641    }
642    /**
643     * Returns a 8x20px, extremely thin font (that may be barely legible) as an embedded resource.
644     * The font builds on work by Christian Munk in his font called Monotwist, making some changes for legibility.
645     * A smaller version of this font, {@link #getTinyFont()}, has the lowest width of any font asset distributed with
646     * SquidLib; this doubles its resolution in case you like its appearance but don't want to go blind. Caches the font
647     * for later calls. Attribution to Christian Munk (or the username he used, CMunk) is required to use this font;
648     * this is in the license file linked below.
649     * <br>
650     * Needs files:
651     * <ul>
652     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Monty-8x20.fnt</li>
653     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Monty-8x20.png</li>
654     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Monty-license.txt</li>
655     * </ul>
656     * @return the BitmapFont object representing Monty.ttf at size 16 pt
657     */

665            } catch (Exception e) {
666            }
667        }

670    /**
671     * Returns a 7x12px font with identical (excellent) Unicode coverage to Iosevka, as an embedded resource.
672     * The font is 7-12-serif by Christian Munk, but not all of the Unicode glyphs supported in his amazingly-huge font
673     * are present here; just the subset that's compatible with Iosevka (which is way more than is required for SquidLib
674     * to present most things). Caches the font for later calls, but be aware that if you copy the BitmapFont instead of
675     * calling this method again, it won't stay monospaced because of a quirk of LibGDX. Attribution to Christian Munk
676     * (or the username he used, CMunk) is required to use this font; this is in the license file linked below.
677     * <br>
678     * Needs files:
679     * <ul>
680     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/7-12-serif.fnt</li>
681     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/7-12-serif.png</li>
682     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/7-12-serif-license.txt</li>
683     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/7-12-serif-readme.txt</li>
684     * </ul>
685     * @return the BitmapFont object representing 7-12-serif.ttf at a size that gives exactly 7 px wide by 12 px tall
686     */
687    public static BitmapFont getSevenTwelveFont()
688    {
689        initialize();
690        if(instance.sevenTwelve == null)
691        {
692            try {
693                instance.sevenTwelve = new BitmapFont(Gdx.files.internal(sevenTwelveName), Gdx.files.internal(sevenTwelveTexture), false);
694            } catch (Exception e) {
695            }
696        }
697        final BitmapFont cpy = copyFont(instance.sevenTwelve);
698        cpy.setFixedWidthGlyphs(" !\"#$%&'()*+,-./0123456789:;<=>?@ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ[\\]^_`abcdefghijklmno\n" +
699                "pqrstuvwxyz{|}~\u00AD\n" +
700                "\n" +
701                "\n" +
702                "\n" +
703                "\n" +
704                "\n" +
705                "\n" +
706                "\n" +
707                "\n" +
708                "\n" +
709                "\n" +
710                "\n" +
711                "\n" +
712                "\n" +
713                "\n" +
714                "\n" +
715                "\n" +
716                "\n" +
717                "\n" +
718                "\n" +
719                "\n" +
720                "\n" +
721                "\n" +
722                "\n" +
723                "\n" +
724                "\n" +
725                "\n" +
726                "\n" +
727                "\u200B\u200C\u200D\u200E\u200F\u2028\u2029\u202A\u202B\u202C\u202D\u202E\n" +
728                "\u2060\u2061\u2062\u2063\u2064\u2066\u2067\u2068\u2069\u206A\u206B\u206C\u206D\u206E\u206F\n" +
729                "\n" +
730                "\n" +
731                "\n" +
732                "\n" +
733                "\n" +
734                "\n" +
735                "\n" +
736                "\n" +
737                "\n" +
738                "\n" +
739                "\n" +
740                "\n" +

759                "\n" +
760                "\n" +
761                "\n" +
762                "\n" +
763                "\n" +
764                "\n" +
765                "\n" +
766                "");
767        return cpy;
768    }
769    /**
770     * Returns a 14x27px font with fairly good Unicode coverage and an octagonal, angular look, as an embedded resource.
771     * The font is Computer Says No by Christian Munk, which has a nice clean appearance. Caches the font for later
772     * calls, but be aware that if you copy the BitmapFont instead of calling this method again, it won't stay
773     * monospaced because of a quirk of LibGDX. Attribution to Christian Munk (or the username he used,
774     * CMunk) is required to use this font; this is in the license file linked below.
775     * <br>
776     * Needs files:
777     * <ul>
778     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/ComputerSaysNo.fnt</li>
779     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/ComputerSaysNo.png</li>
780     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/ComputerSaysNo-license.txt</li>
781     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/ComputerSaysNo-readme.txt</li>
782     * </ul>
783     * @return the BitmapFont object representing ComputerSaysNo.ttf at a size that gives about 14 px wide by 27 px tall
784     */
785    public static BitmapFont getOctagonalMonoFont()
786    {
787        initialize();
788        if(instance.computerSaysNo == null)
789        {
790            try {
791                instance.computerSaysNo = new BitmapFont(Gdx.files.internal(computerSaysNoName), Gdx.files.internal(computerSaysNoTexture), false);
792            } catch (Exception e) {
793                instance.computerSaysNo = new BitmapFont();
794            }
795        }
796        final BitmapFont cpy = copyFont(instance.computerSaysNo);
797        // ugh, this shouldn't be required...
798        cpy.setFixedWidthGlyphs("\u0000" +
799                " !\"#$%&'()*+,-./0123456789:;<=>?@ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ[\\]^_`abcdefghijklmno\n" +
800                "pqrstuvwxyz{|}~\u00AD\n" +
801                "\n" +
802                "\n" +
803                "\n" +
804                "\n" +
805                "\n" +
806                "\n" +
807                "\n" +
808                "\n" +
809                "\n" +
810                "\n" +
811                "\n" +
812                "\n" +
813                "\n" +
814                "\n" +
815                "\n" +
816                "\n" +
817                "\n" +
818                "\n" +
819                "\n" +
820                "\n" +
821                "\n" +
822                "\n" +
823                "\n" +
824                "\n" +
825                "\n" +
826                "\n" +
827                "\n" +
828                "\n" +
829                "\n" +
830                "\n" +
831                "\n" +
832                "");
833        return cpy;
834    }
835
836    /**
837     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a square font that should scale cleanly to many sizes. Caches
838     * the result for later calls.
839     * <br>
840     * Preview: http://i.imgur.com/DD1RkPa.png
841     * <br>
842     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
843     * distance field font technique this uses can work.
844     * <br>
845     * Needs files:
846     * <ul>
847     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Inconsolata-LGC-Square-distance.fnt</li>
848     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Inconsolata-LGC-Square-distance.png</li>
849     * </ul>
850     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the square font Inconsolata-LGC-Square.ttf
851     */
852    public static TextCellFactory getStretchableSquareFont()
853    {
854        initialize();
855        if(instance.distanceSquare == null)
856        {
857            try {
858                instance.distanceSquare = new TextCellFactory().defaultDistanceFieldFont();
859            } catch (Exception e) {
860            }
861        }
862        if(instance.distanceSquare != null)
863            return instance.distanceSquare.copy();
864        return null;
865    }
866
867    /**
868     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use an blocky, fairly-bold square font that should scale cleanly
869     * to many sizes. Unlike {@link #getStretchableSquareFont()}, the font this uses was made to be square initially,
870     * and is not a distorted/stretched version of an existing font. Caches the result for later calls.
871     * <br>
872     * <a href="https://i.imgur.com/nIjgTOp.png">Preview at 6x6 size, https://i.imgur.com/nIjgTOp.png</a>
873     * <a href="https://i.imgur.com/lWaSgVN.png">Preview at much larger size, https://i.imgur.com/lWaSgVN.png</a>
874     * <br>
875     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
876     * distance field font technique this uses can work.
877     * <br>
878     * Needs files:
879     * <ul>
880     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/BoxedIn-distance.fnt</li>
881     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/BoxedIn-distance.png</li>
882     * </ul>
883     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the square font BoxedIn.ttf
884     */
885    public static TextCellFactory getStretchableHeavySquareFont()
886    {
887        initialize();
888        if(instance.distanceHeavySquare == null)
889        {
890            try {
891                instance.distanceHeavySquare = new TextCellFactory()
892                        .fontDistanceField(distanceFieldHeavySquare, distanceFieldHeavySquareTexture)
893                        .setSmoothingMultiplier(2.125f);
894            } catch (Exception e) {
895            }
896        }
897        if(instance.distanceHeavySquare != null)
898            return instance.distanceHeavySquare.copy();
899        return null;
900    }
901
902    /**
903     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use an all-caps (with lighter-weight versions of upper-case
904     * letters for the lower-case glyphs) square font that should scale cleanly to many sizes.
905     * Unlike {@link #getStretchableSquareFont()}, the font this uses was made to be square initially, and is not a
906     * distorted/stretched version of an existing font. This font only supports ASCII, and as said before, it doesn't
907     * have separate lower-case letters. Note: if you use this font as-is, most characters will overlap slightly with
908     * each other, which can be an aesthetic benefit in some styles but can also be hard to read, at least if the colors
909     * aren't different between overlapping characters. For that reason, you may want to tweak the width and height of
910     * this font after passing it to a SquidLayers or SparseLayers; often you would pass 0.875 times the original
911     * width and height to {@link TextCellFactory#tweakWidth(float)} and {@link TextCellFactory#tweakHeight(float)}.
912     * Caches the result for later calls. The font is "square" by Wouter van Oortmerssen; it is available under a
913     * CC-BY-3.0 license, which requires attribution to Wouter van Oortmerssen if you use it.
914     * <br>
915     * <a href="https://i.imgur.com/nvHl64v.png">Preview at large size</a>
916     * <br>
917     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
918     * distance field font technique this uses can work.
919     * <br>
920     * Needs files:
921     * <ul>
922     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/square-msdf.fnt</li>
923     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/square-msdf.png</li>
924     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/square-License.txt</li>
925     * </ul>
926     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font square.ttf
927     */
928    public static TextCellFactory getCrispCurvySquareFont()
929    {
930        initialize();
931        if(instance.msdfCurvySquare == null)
932        {
933            try {
934                instance.msdfCurvySquare = new TextCellFactory()
935                        .fontMultiDistanceField(crispCurvySquare, crispCurvySquareTexture).setSmoothingMultiplier(6f);
936            } catch (Exception e) {
937            }
938        }
939        if(instance.msdfCurvySquare != null)
940            return instance.msdfCurvySquare.copy();
941        return null;
942    }

945    /**
946     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a narrow font (twice as tall as it is wide) that should scale
947     * cleanly to many sizes. Caches the result for later calls.
948     * <br>
949     * Preview: http://i.imgur.com/dvEEMqo.png
950     * <br>
951     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
952     * distance field font technique this uses can work.
953     * <br>
954     * Needs files:
955     * <ul>
956     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Inconsolata-LGC-Custom-distance.fnt</li>
957     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Inconsolata-LGC-Custom-distance.png</li>
958     * </ul>
959     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font Inconsolata-LGC-Custom.ttf
960     */
961    public static TextCellFactory getStretchableFont()
962    {
963        initialize();
964        if(instance.distanceNarrow == null)
965        {
966            try {
967                instance.distanceNarrow = new TextCellFactory().defaultNarrowDistanceFieldFont();
968            } catch (Exception e) {
969                e.printStackTrace();
970            }
971        }
972        if(instance.distanceNarrow != null)
973            return instance.distanceNarrow.copy();
974        return null;
975
976    }

1010    /**
1011     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a highly-legible fixed-width font with broad Unicode support
1012     * that should scale cleanly to many sizes. Caches the result for later calls. The font used is Source Code Pro, an
1013     * open-source (SIL Open Font License) typeface by Adobe, and it has good Unicode support among the fixed-width
1014     * fonts used by SquidLib. It may be a good choice for science-fiction games because of its modern feel, but the
1015     * legibility enhancements made so the font could be usable in text editors also are nice for all text-based games.
1016     * The high glyph count means the part of the image for each glyph is smaller, though, so this may look slightly
1017     * pixelated if it starts small and is resized to much larger. A cell width of 15 and cell height of 27 is ideal;
1018     * this allows the font to resize fairly well to larger sizes using Viewports.
1019     * <br>
1020     * Preview: http://i.imgur.com/VC0xn2r.png
1021     * <br>
1022     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
1023     * distance field font technique this uses can work.
1024     * <br>
1025     * Needs files:
1026     * <ul>
1027     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/SourceCodePro-Medium-distance.fnt</li>
1028     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/SourceCodePro-Medium-distance.png</li>
1029     * </ul>
1030     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font SourceCodePro-Medium.otf
1031     */
1032    public static TextCellFactory getStretchableCodeFont()
1033    {
1034        initialize();
1035        if(instance.distanceCode == null)
1036        {
1037            try {
1038                instance.distanceCode = new TextCellFactory()
1039                        .fontDistanceField(distanceFieldCode, distanceFieldCodeTexture);
1040            } catch (Exception e) {
1041                e.printStackTrace();
1042            }
1043        }
1044        if(instance.distanceCode != null)
1045            return instance.distanceCode.copy();
1046        return null;
1047    }
1048    /**
1049     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a highly-legible fixed-width font with strong CJK support (in
1050     * particular, very good coverage for Japanese) that should scale cleanly to many sizes. Caches the result for later
1051     * calls. The font used is Source Han Code JP, an open-source (SIL Open Font License) typeface by Adobe, and it has
1052     * the best CJK char support among the fonts used by SquidLib. It is extremely wide if used only for English text,
1053     * which may be desirable to make square cells. The very high glyph count means the part of the image for each glyph
1054     * is smaller, though, so this may look slightly pixelated if it starts small and is resized to much larger. A cell
1055     * width of 19 and cell height of 20 is ideal; this allows the font to resize fairly well to larger sizes.
1056     * <br>
1057     * Preview: https://i.imgur.com/g65jXxB.png
1058     * <br>
1059     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
1060     * distance field font technique this uses can work.
1061     * <br>
1062     * Needs files:
1063     * <ul>
1064     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/SourceHanCodeJP-Regular-distance.fnt</li>
1065     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/SourceHanCodeJP-Regular-distance.png</li>
1066     * </ul>
1067     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font SourceHanCodeJP-Regular.otf
1068     */
1069    public static TextCellFactory getStretchableCodeJPFont()
1070    {
1071        initialize();
1072        if(instance.distanceCodeJP == null)
1073        {
1074            try {
1075                instance.distanceCodeJP = new TextCellFactory()
1076                        .fontDistanceField(distanceFieldCodeJP, distanceFieldCodeJPTexture).setSmoothingMultiplier(1.125f);
1077            } catch (Exception e) {
1078                e.printStackTrace();
1079            }
1080        }
1081        if(instance.distanceCodeJP != null)
1082            return instance.distanceCodeJP.copy();
1083        return null;
1084    }
1085    /**
1086     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a highly-legible fixed-width font with good Unicode support
1087     * and a thin, geometric style, that should scale cleanly to many sizes. Caches the result for later calls. The font
1088     * used is Iosevka, an open-source (SIL Open Font License) typeface by Belleve Invis (see
1089     * https://be5invis.github.io/Iosevka/ ), and it uses several customizations thanks to Iosevka's special build
1090     * process. It supports a lot of glyphs, including quite a bit of extended Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic, but also
1091     * circled letters and digits and the necessary box drawing characters. The high glyph count means the part of the
1092     * image for each glyph is smaller, though, so this may look slightly pixelated if it starts small and is resized to
1093     * much larger. A cell width of 11 and cell height of 20 is ideal (or some approximate multiple of that aspect
1094     * ratio); this allows the font to resize fairly well to larger sizes using Viewports. As an aside, Luc Devroye (a
1095     * true typography expert) called Iosevka <a href="http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-82704.html">"A tour de force that
1096     * deserves an award."</a> You may want to try using both this sans-serif version of Iosevka and the slab-serif
1097     * version SquidLib has, {@link #getStretchableSlabFont()}, though they have subtly different sizes. There are
1098     * also versions of Iosevka that use a Light weight, available by {@link #getStretchableLeanLightFont()} and
1099     * {@link #getStretchableSlabLightFont()}.
1100     * <br>
1101     * Preview: http://i.imgur.com/sm0ULbU.png
1102     * <br>
1103     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
1104     * distance field font technique this uses can work.
1105     * <br>
1106     * Needs files:
1107     * <ul>
1108     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Iosevka-distance.fnt</li>
1109     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Iosevka-distance.png</li>
1110     * </ul>
1111     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font Iosevka.ttf
1112     */
1113    public static TextCellFactory getStretchableLeanFont()
1114    {
1115        initialize();
1116        if(instance.distanceLean == null)
1117        {
1118            try {
1119                instance.distanceLean = new TextCellFactory()
1120                        .fontDistanceField(distanceFieldLean, distanceFieldLeanTexture);
1121            } catch (Exception e) {
1122                e.printStackTrace();
1123            }
1124        }
1125        if(instance.distanceLean != null)
1126            return instance.distanceLean.copy();
1127        return null;
1128    }

1130    /**
1131     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a highly-legible fixed-width font with good Unicode support
1132     * and a slab-serif geometric style, that should scale cleanly to many sizes. Caches the result for later calls. The
1133     * font used is Iosevka with Slab style, an open-source (SIL Open Font License) typeface by Belleve Invis (see
1134     * https://be5invis.github.io/Iosevka/ ), and it uses several customizations thanks to Iosevka's special build
1135     * process. It supports a lot of glyphs, including quite a bit of extended Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic, but also
1136     * circled letters and digits and the necessary box drawing characters. The high glyph count means the part of the
1137     * image for each glyph is smaller, though, so this may look slightly pixelated if it starts small and is resized to
1138     * much larger. A cell width of 11 and cell height of 20 is ideal (or some approximate multiple of that aspect
1139     * ratio); this allows the font to resize fairly well to larger sizes using Viewports. As an aside, Luc Devroye (a
1140     * true typography expert) called Iosevka <a href="http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-82704.html">"A tour de force that
1141     * deserves an award."</a> You may want to try using both this version of Iosevka with slab serifs and the other
1142     * version SquidLib has, {@link #getStretchableLeanFont()}, though they have subtly different sizes. There are
1143     * also versions of Iosevka that use a Light weight, available by {@link #getStretchableLeanLightFont()} and
1144     * {@link #getStretchableSlabLightFont()}.

1149     * distance field font technique this uses can work.

1152     * <ul>

1154     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Iosevka-Slab-distance.png</li>
1155     * </ul>
1156     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font Iosevka-Slab.ttf

1167                e.printStackTrace();

1169        }
1170        if(instance.distanceSlab != null)
1171            return instance.distanceSlab.copy();
1172        return null;

1174    /**
1175     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a highly-legible fixed-width font with good Unicode support
1176     * and a very thin, geometric style, that should scale cleanly to many sizes. Caches the result for later calls. The
1177     * font used is Iosevka (at Light weight), an open-source (SIL Open Font License) typeface by Belleve Invis (see
1178     * https://be5invis.github.io/Iosevka/ ), and it uses several customizations thanks to Iosevka's special build
1179     * process. It supports a lot of glyphs, including quite a bit of extended Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic, but also
1180     * circled letters and digits and the necessary box drawing characters. The high glyph count means the part of the
1181     * image for each glyph is smaller, though, so this may look slightly pixelated if it starts small and is resized to
1182     * much larger. A cell width of 11 and cell height of 20 is ideal (or some approximate multiple of that aspect
1183     * ratio); this allows the font to resize fairly well to larger sizes using Viewports. As an aside, Luc Devroye (a
1184     * true typography expert) called Iosevka <a href="http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-82704.html">"A tour de force that
1185     * deserves an award."</a> You may want to try using both this sans-serif version of Iosevka and the slab-serif
1186     * version SquidLib has, {@link #getStretchableSlabLightFont()}, though they have subtly different sizes. There are
1187     * also versions of Iosevka that do not use this Light weight, available by {@link #getStretchableLeanFont()} and

1229     * aside, Luc Devroye (a true typography expert) called Iosevka <a href="http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-82704.html">"A
1230     * tour de force that deserves an award."</a> You may want to try using both this version of Iosevka with slab

1264    /**
1265     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a font with extremely wide Unicode support that should scale
1266     * cleanly to many sizes. Caches the result for later calls. The font is DejaVu Sans Mono, a common font on Linux
1267     * operating systems and a clean-looking, legible font, though it has some visual quirks like a "tail" on lower-case
1268     * 'l', that take some getting used to. A possible requirement for this font is that the size of the text in a
1269     * SquidPanel or SquidLayers may need to be increased 1-5 pixels past what the cell width and height are; this can
1270     * be done with {@link SquidPanel#setTextSize(float, float)} or {@link SquidLayers#setTextSize(float, float)},
1271     * giving 1-2 more than the cell width for x and 3-5 more than the cell height for y.

1276     * distance field font technique this uses can work.

1280     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/DejaVuSansMono-distance.fnt</li>
1281     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/DejaVuSansMono-distance.png</li>
1282     * </ul>
1283     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font DejaVuSansMono.ttf
1284     */
1285    public static TextCellFactory getStretchableDejaVuFont()

1289        {
1290            try {
1291                instance.distanceDejaVu = new TextCellFactory().fontDistanceField(distanceFieldDejaVu, distanceFieldDejaVuTexture);
1292            } catch (Exception e) {
1293                e.printStackTrace();
1294            }
1295        }

1298        return null;

1301    /**
1302     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a variable-width serif font that should look like the serif
1303     * fonts used in many novels' main texts, and that should scale cleanly to many sizes. Meant to be used in variable-
1304     * width displays like TextPanel. Caches the result for later calls.
1305     * <br>
1306     * Preview: http://i.imgur.com/eIYYt8C.png
1307     * <br>
1308     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
1309     * distance field font technique this uses can work.
1310     * <br>
1311     * Needs files:
1312     * <ul>
1313     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Gentium-distance.fnt</li>
1314     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Gentium-distance.png</li>
1315     * </ul>
1316     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font Gentium, by SIL
1317     */
1318    public static TextCellFactory getStretchablePrintFont() {
1319        initialize();
1320        if (instance.distancePrint == null) {
1321            try {
1322                instance.distancePrint = new TextCellFactory().fontDistanceField(distanceFieldPrint, distanceFieldPrintTexture)
1323                        .height(30).width(7);
1324                instance.distancePrint.bmpFont.setUseIntegerPositions(false);
1325                
1326            } catch (Exception e) {
1327                e.printStackTrace();
1328            }
1329        }
1330        if(instance.distancePrint != null)
1331            return instance.distancePrint.copy();
1332        return null;
1333    }
1334
1335    /**
1336     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a variable-width sans-serif font that should have a blocky,
1337     * futuristic look (based on the font Orbitron), and that should scale cleanly to many sizes. Meant to be used in
1338     * variable-width displays like TextPanel. Caches the result for later calls.
1339     * <br>
1340     * Preview: http://i.imgur.com/grJhoMs.png
1341     * <br>
1342     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
1343     * distance field font technique this uses can work.
1344     * <br>
1345     * Needs files:
1346     * <ul>
1347     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Orbitron-distance.fnt</li>
1348     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Orbitron-distance.png</li>
1349     * </ul>
1350     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font Orbitron, by The League of Movable Type
1351     */
1352    public static TextCellFactory getStretchableOrbitFont() {
1353        initialize();
1354        if (instance.distanceOrbit == null) {
1355            try {
1356                instance.distanceOrbit = new TextCellFactory().setDirectionGlyph('')
1357                        .fontDistanceField(distanceFieldOrbit, distanceFieldOrbitTexture)
1358                        .setSmoothingMultiplier(1.3f).height(30).width(11);
1359            } catch (Exception e) {
1360                e.printStackTrace();
1361            }
1362        }
1363        if(instance.distanceOrbit != null)
1364            return instance.distanceOrbit.copy();
1365        return null;
1366    }

1368    /**
1369     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a variable-width sans-serif font that currently looks
1370     * slightly jumbled without certain layout features. Meant to be used in variable-width displays like TextPanel, but
1371     * currently you should prefer getStretchablePrintFont() for legibility. Caches the result for later calls.
1372     * <br>
1373     * Preview: http://i.imgur.com/GF5qQxn.png
1374     * <br>
1375     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
1376     * distance field font technique this uses can work. Sets the smoothing multiplier to 0.8f; if you set the smoothing
1377     * multiplier yourself, it should be similarly smaller than what other fonts use (most fonts are 1.0, so multiplying
1378     * whatever you would normally set the smoothing multiplier to by 0.8f should work).
1379     * <br>
1380     * Needs files:
1381     * <ul>
1382     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Noto-Sans-distance.fnt</li>
1383     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Noto-Sans-distance.png</li>
1384     * </ul>
1385     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font Noto Sans, by Google
1386     */
1387    public static TextCellFactory getStretchableCleanFont() {
1388        initialize();
1389        if (instance.distanceClean == null) {
1390            try {
1391                instance.distanceClean = new TextCellFactory().fontDistanceField(distanceFieldClean, distanceFieldCleanTexture)
1392                        .setSmoothingMultiplier(0.8f).height(30).width(5);
1393            } catch (Exception e) {
1394                e.printStackTrace();
1395            }
1396        }
1397        if(instance.distanceClean != null)
1398            return instance.distanceClean.copy();
1399        return null;
1400    }
1401
1402    /**
1403     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a highly-legible fixed-width font with good Unicode support
1404     * and a slab-serif geometric style, that should scale cleanly to even very large sizes (using an MSDF technique).
1405     * Caches the result for later calls. The font used is Iosevka with Slab style, an open-source (SIL Open Font
1406     * License) typeface by Belleve Invis (see https://be5invis.github.io/Iosevka/ ), and it uses several customizations
1407     * thanks to Iosevka's special build process. It supports a lot of glyphs, including quite a bit of extended Latin,
1408     * Greek, and Cyrillic, but also the necessary box drawing characters. This uses the Multi-channel Signed Distance
1409     * Field (MSDF) technique as opposed to the normal Signed Distance Field technique, which gives the rendered font
1410     * sharper edges and precise corners instead of rounded tips on strokes. As an aside, Luc Devroye (a true typography
1411     * expert) called Iosevka
1412     * <a href="http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-82704.html">"A tour de force that deserves an award."</a>
1413     * <br>
1414     * Preview: <a href="https://i.imgur.com/YlzFEVX.png">Image link</a>
1415     * <br>
1416     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
1417     * multi-channel distance field font technique this uses can work.
1418     * <br>
1419     * Needs files:
1420     * <ul>
1421     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Iosevka-Slab-msdf.fnt</li>
1422     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Iosevka-Slab-msdf.png</li>
1423     * </ul>
1424     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font Iosevka-Slab.ttf using MSDF
1425     */
1426    public static TextCellFactory getCrispSlabFont()
1427    {
1428        initialize();
1429        if(instance.msdfSlab == null)
1430        {
1431            try {
1432                instance.msdfSlab = new TextCellFactory()
1433                        .fontMultiDistanceField(crispSlab, crispSlabTexture);
1434            } catch (Exception e) {
1435                e.printStackTrace();
1436            }
1437        }
1438        if(instance.msdfSlab != null)
1439            return instance.msdfSlab.copy();
1440        return null;
1441    }
1442    /**
1443     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a highly-legible oblique (similar to italic) fixed-width font
1444     * with good Unicode support and a slab-serif geometric style, that should scale cleanly to even very large sizes
1445     * (using an MSDF technique). Caches the result for later calls. The font used is Iosevka with Oblique Slab style,
1446     * an open-source (SIL Open Font License) typeface by Belleve Invis (see https://be5invis.github.io/Iosevka/ ), and
1447     * it uses several customizations thanks to Iosevka's special build process. It supports a lot of glyphs, including
1448     * quite a bit of extended Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic, but also the necessary box drawing characters. This uses the
1449     * Multi-channel Signed Distance Field (MSDF) technique as opposed to the normal Signed Distance Field technique,
1450     * which gives the rendered font sharper edges and precise corners instead of rounded tips on strokes. As an aside,
1451     * Luc Devroye (a true typography expert) called Iosevka
1452     * <a href="http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-82704.html">"A tour de force that deserves an award."</a>
1453     * <br>
1454     * Preview: <a href="https://i.imgur.com/njA1ae1.png">Image link</a>
1455     * <br>
1456     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
1457     * multi-channel distance field font technique this uses can work.
1458     * <br>
1459     * Needs files:
1460     * <ul>
1461     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Iosevka-Slab-Oblique-msdf.fnt</li>

1463     * </ul>

1465     */

1467    {

1470        {
1471            try {
1472                instance.msdfSlabItalic = new TextCellFactory()
1473                        .fontMultiDistanceField(crispSlabItalic, crispSlabItalicTexture);
1474            } catch (Exception e) {
1475                e.printStackTrace();
1476            }
1477        }
1478        if(instance.msdfSlabItalic != null)
1479            return instance.msdfSlabItalic.copy();
1480        return null;
1481    }

1562    /**
1563     * Returns a TextCellFactory already configured to use a fixed-width sans-serif font with excellent Unicode support,
1564     * that should scale cleanly to even very large sizes. Caches the result for later calls. The font used is DejaVu
1565     * Sans Mono, an open-source (SIL Open Font License) typeface that is widely used by Linux distros and other groups.
1566     * It supports a lot of glyphs, including quite a bit of extended Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic, but also the
1567     * necessary box drawing characters. This uses the Multi-channel Signed Distance Field technique as opposed to the
1568     * normal Signed Distance Field technique, which should allow sharper edges. It has been updated so it is laid out
1569     * mostly-correctly now; some glyphs may be a little wide, such as {@code @}, but the line height, baseline, and the
1570     * width for most glyphs seem correct. You may need to tweak the size more for width than for height (recommended to
1571     * have box drawing characters line up is, after giving an initially-sized TextCellFactory to a class like
1572     * SquidLayers, SparseLayers, or SquidPanel, to call {@link TextCellFactory#tweakWidth(float)} with 1.125f times the
1573     * original width and {@link TextCellFactory#tweakHeight(float)} with 1.075f times the original height).
1574     * <br>
1575     * Preview: <a href="https://i.imgur.com/SCwhduv.png">Image link</a>
1576     * <br>
1577     * This creates a TextCellFactory instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
1578     * multi-channel distance field font technique this uses can work.
1579     * <br>
1580     * Needs files:
1581     * <ul>
1582     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/DejaVuSansMono-msdf.fnt</li>
1583     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/DejaVuSansMono-msdf.png</li>
1584     * </ul>
1585     * @return the TextCellFactory object that can represent many sizes of the font DejaVuSansMono.ttf with an MSDF effect
1586     */
1587    public static TextCellFactory getCrispDejaVuFont()
1588    {
1589        initialize();
1590        if(instance.msdfDejaVu == null)
1591        {
1592            try {
1593                instance.msdfDejaVu = new TextCellFactory()
1594                        .fontMultiDistanceField(crispDejaVu, crispDejaVuTexture).setSmoothingMultiplier(1f);
1595            } catch (Exception e) {
1596                e.printStackTrace();
1597            }
1598        }
1599        if(instance.msdfDejaVu != null)
1600            return instance.msdfDejaVu.copy();
1601        return null;
1602    }

1645    /**
1646     * Returns a TextFamily already configured to use a highly-legible fixed-width font with good Unicode support and a
1647     * slab-serif geometric style, that should scale cleanly to many sizes and supports 4 styles (regular, bold, italic,
1648     * and bold italic). Caches the result for later calls. The font used is Iosevka with Slab style, an open-source
1649     * (SIL Open Font License) typeface by Belleve Invis (see https://be5invis.github.io/Iosevka/ ), and it uses several
1650     * customizations thanks to Iosevka's special build process, applied to the 4 styles. It supports a lot of glyphs,
1651     * including quite a bit of extended Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic, but also circled letters and digits and the
1652     * necessary box drawing characters (which line up even for italic text). The high glyph count means the part of the
1653     * image for each glyph is smaller, though, so this may look slightly pixelated if it starts small and is resized to
1654     * much larger. A cell width of 11 and cell height of 20 is ideal (or some approximate multiple of that aspect
1655     * ratio); this allows the font to resize fairly well to larger sizes using Viewports. As an aside, Luc Devroye (a
1656     * true typography expert) called Iosevka <a href="http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-82704.html">"A tour de force that
1657     * deserves an award."</a> You may want to try using both this version of Iosevka with slab serifs and the other
1658     * version SquidLib has, {@link #getLeanFamily()}.
1659     * <br>
1660     * <br>
1661     * This creates a TextFamily instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
1662     * distance field font technique this uses can work, but it can also be used as a TextCellFactory.
1663     * <br>
1664     * Needs files:
1665     * <ul>
1666     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Iosevka-Slab-Family-distance.fnt</li>
1667     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Iosevka-Slab-Family-distance.png</li>
1668     * </ul>
1669     * @return the TextFamily object that can represent many sizes of the font Iosevka-Slab.ttf with 4 styles
1670     */
1671    public static TextFamily getSlabFamily()
1672    {
1673        initialize();
1674        if(instance.familySlab == null)
1675        {
1676            try {
1677                instance.familySlab = new TextFamily().defaultFamilySlabDistance();
1678            } catch (Exception e) {
1679                e.printStackTrace();
1680            }
1681        }
1682        if(instance.familySlab != null)
1683            return instance.familySlab.copy();
1684        return null;
1685    }
1686    /**
1687     * Returns a TextFamily already configured to use a highly-legible fixed-width font with good Unicode support and a
1688     * sans-serif geometric style, that should scale cleanly to many sizes and supports 4 styles (regular, bold, italic,
1689     * and bold italic). Caches the result for later calls. The font used is Iosevka, an open-source (SIL Open Font
1690     * License) typeface by Belleve Invis (see https://be5invis.github.io/Iosevka/ ), and it uses several customizations
1691     * thanks to Iosevka's special build process, applied to the 4 styles. It supports a lot of glyphs, including quite
1692     * a bit of extended Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic, but also circled letters and digits and the necessary box drawing
1693     * characters (which line up even for italic text). The high glyph count means the part of the image for each glyph
1694     * is smaller, though, so this may look slightly pixelated if it starts small and is resized to much larger. A cell
1695     * width of 11 and cell height of 20 is ideal (or some approximate multiple of that aspect ratio); this allows the
1696     * font to resize fairly well to larger sizes using Viewports. As an aside, Luc Devroye (a true typography expert)
1697     * called Iosevka <a href="http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-82704.html">"A tour de force that deserves an award."</a>
1698     * You may want to try using both this version of Iosevka without serifs and the other version SquidLib has,
1699     * {@link #getSlabFamily()}.
1700     * <br>
1701     * <br>
1702     * This creates a TextFamily instead of a BitmapFont because it needs to set some extra information so the
1703     * distance field font technique this uses can work, but it can also be used as a TextCellFactory.
1704     * <br>
1705     * Needs files:
1706     * <ul>
1707     *     <li>https://github.com/SquidPony/SquidLib/blob/master/assets/Iosevka-Family-distance.fnt</li>

1709     * </ul>

1716        {
